bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h2>üêõ Bug</denchmark-h>
When trying to install locally by running pip install -r requirements.txt the following error can occur depending on the CUDA version installed: <denchmark-code>ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement torch>=1.6.0 (from -r requirements.txt (line 12)) (from versions: 0.1.2, 0.1.2.post1, 0.1.2.post2) ERROR: No matching distribution found for torch>=1.6.0 (from -r requirements.txt (line 12)) </denchmark-code>
Running then (as specified by pytorch <denchmark-link:https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/>here</denchmark-link> ) solved this for me. <denchmark-h:h2>To Reproduce (REQUIRED)</denchmark-h>
Trying to install in a fresh environment in Windows with CUDA 10.1 <denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
Update readme to remove previous CUDA versions or give info on this error. I think this is an issue with pytorch which requires specifique commands to install depending on environment so I'm not sure there is much you can do. It would be nice to be able to run pip install -r requirements.txt without having preinstalled pytorch if possible. <denchmark-h:h2>Environment</denchmark-h>
OS: Windows GPU RTX 2060 CUDA: 10.1
<denchmark-h:h2>Additional context</denchmark-h>

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/robin-maillot>@robin-maillot</denchmark-link> torch installations may always need a bit of finetuning to specific scenarios. In our CI tests for example, which run on a CPU-only instance, we specify a CPU-only installation of torch: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/actions/runs/288465315/workflow#L44-L51>https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov5/actions/runs/288465315/workflow#L44-L51</denchmark-link>
- name: Install dependencies run: | python -m pip install --upgrade pip pip install -qr requirements.txt -f https://download.pytorch.org/whl/cpu/torch_stable.html pip install -q onnx python --version pip --version pip list Also if you have legacy CUDA installations those need to be specified as shown in linux install commands, i.e. <denchmark-link:https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/>https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/</denchmark-link>
Windows commands will also differ, so there's really no one size fits all solution. The presented solutions are mainly directed to linux users with the latest version of cuda, which can simply use the default pip install torch commands. We could consider adding this link if it was robust to installations across all operating systems (linux, macos, windows) and all hardware configurations (CUDA, CPU only). Would it be possible for you to test these cases and and then submit a PR with what you find to work best?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/glenn-jocher>@glenn-jocher</denchmark-link> I will have a look this week but can you give me a bit more information about the installation conditions:
Do you need the user to be able to install a CPU version when running on a machine with a gpu available? Or is the CPU only needed when no GPU is available?
For me (with outdated CUDA versions due to tensorflow requirements) I did not have to run the command recommended by pytorch simply running pip install torch -f https://download.pytorch.org/whl/torch_stable.html worked. I have not tested this with CUDA<10.1 but I can try this weekend. A quick fix could be just to add the pytorch link (<denchmark-link:https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/>https://pytorch.org/get-started/locally/</denchmark-link> ) in the readme and warn the user that there might can be issues with previous cuda versions.
